posts.name: midknight
posts.cooked:
Context

Huawei is currently releasing their new OS in mainland China and you cannot use any android apps (apks) anymore and have to build your own version made for that platform.

Currently few messaging apps are being used except WeChat obviously so bringing Signal there would be a great idea.

OS

  • HarmonyOS: https://developer.huawei.com/consumer/cn/ (Chinese only)
  • OpenHarmony
    • Website: https://www.openharmony.cn/ (Chinese only)
    • Sources: https://gitee.com/openharmony

Development

  • HarmonyOS NEXT Guides: https://developer.huawei.com/consumer/en/doc/harmonyos-guides-V5/application-dev-guide-V5 (Multilingual)
  • OpenHarmony Guides: https://docs.openharmony.cn/pages/v5.0/en/application-dev/application-dev-guide.md (Multilingual)

posts.cooked:
Hello, and welcome.

Signal is an app built and owned by a charity, and the software philosophy is one of privacy and collecting as little data as possible. Itâ€™s unlikely resources will be dedicated to building and maintaining an entire second service when staffing, infrastructure, and maintenance for the existing Signal service alone costs $50M/year.

Signal only promises to be secure if the underlying OS is secure. You can just about guarantee that HarmonyOS is PRC spyware, so thereâ€™s no way to make Signal secure over there.

Porting Signal to HarmonyOS would just be security theater.

Hybrima:

HarmonyOS is PRC spyware

Just like Android and iOS are US spyware. China already spies on its citizens using Android and iOS.

Letâ€™s find out.

Which of the following is, in your opinion, Spyware?

  • Android
  • iOS
  • Harmony OS
0 voters

Totally agree, which is why I run Free (as in Freedom) OSs on my phone and computers.

I consider Windows, MacOS, iOS, and Android to be suspect. Any proprietary software is. But also, I understand that it is more work to run a fully free OS and many people just arenâ€™t going to do that.

But seriously, anything developed in China is extraordinarily unsafe and untrustworthy. Far more so than Windows, MacOS, iOS, and Android.

The most unbiased individuals voted for all three options, as it is the most fair choice. However, I am surprised that iOS received the fewest votes, especially considering it is the only closed-source operating system. When analyzing internet traffic, all operating systems have some questionable connections. However, this is not solely about traffic, as all three operating systems likely have some form of backdoors.

Hybrima:

But seriously, anything developed in China is extraordinarily unsafe and untrustworthy. Far more so than Windows, MacOS, iOS, and Android.

Why do you think this way? For me, it seems like the marketing and propaganda of one side have been more effective than the other, particularly in this case, the West over China. Media can be misleading, and sometimes we see how US media tries to denigrate other countries they donâ€™t like (and vice versa), but thatâ€™s not always true. Just browsing YouTube can reveal how many lies we are fed. So for me, they are all the same in terms of spying. Itâ€™s just that some people prefer to believe the marketing and propaganda of one side over the other.

defltare:

Why do you think this way?

I wonder why?
Imagine posting this and not realizing that America has the same thing have you ever heard of a credit score? Lol

Imagine thinking Chinaâ€™s social credit system is in any way similar to a credit score in America. LOL.

Hint: Chinaâ€™s social credit system is based on your beliefs and who you associate with. Americaâ€™s credit score is nothing like that. Itâ€™s based on whether you have taken out a loan and did you pay it back on time. But, please, go on.

If you donâ€™t want to be a slave to debt, start listening to Dave Ramsey. Heâ€™ll explain why you donâ€™t want to ever take out a loan and why building your credit score is a scam. He also has great advice on how to dig your way out of debt if you find yourself in deep.

posts.name: Pickle
posts.cooked:
At the end of the day, itâ€™s a brand new system, so it wonâ€™t have many users yet. I donâ€™t think the Signal team would see the value in investing their time and money into developing a brand new client for this system. Maybe in the future if the system becomes extremely popular it would make more sense to make a native client. Right now, I think it would just make more sense to focus on the current platforms, as I donâ€™t think theyâ€™re even at feature parity yet. Adding another system would take resources away from the current apps.

Thankfully, Signal is open source. If this system does get widespread adoption someone (maybe even one of you reading this) will likely make a new client or fork to support this system.

Also, I think supporting Flatpak officially would be the next logical step in supporting new systems.
